dataset_name: TJO Universal Cone System Canonical Truth Set

application: Revision total knee arthroplasty (TKA) metaphyseal fixation
core_positioning: Universal geometry: one cone system for tibia + femur
Multiple taper angles (12°, 18°, 24°) to improve femoral fit and conserve bone
Small footprint instrumentation (1 tray for cones; 3 trays for full revision system)

material.coating_description: Ultra-porous commercially pure titanium coating created by sintering asymmetrical grains

porosity.purpose: Facilitate biologic fixation and bony ingrowth

material.internal_surface: Grit-blasted with machined steps to optimize cement mantle adherence

dimensions.keel_cutout_purpose: Clearance for the keel of the largest (Size 6) Klassic® Tibial Baseplate

compatibility.universal_geometry: Designed for use in both the femur and tibia

tibia.note: Keel cutouts must be oriented M/L for tibial implant clearance

femur.note: Keel cutouts must be oriented A/P (rotated 90° from tibia) for femoral implant clearance

klassic_femur_compatibility.constraint_note: Larger cones may not fit inside the box of the smallest femurs

competitive_cross_compatibility_sales_in.key_point: Size 2 cone (~18mm ID) can fit over many competitor stem housings to enable isolated cone revisions without changing the primary system

system_footprint.cone_tray_details: One 1/2-height tray can be used for both femur and tibia cones and includes trials for both sides
system_footprint.competitive_context: Competitors often require 8–12+ trays; some use 15–18 trays with double-decker back tables

prep_method.claimed_benefit: Reduces fracture risk compared to broaching/burring techniques

reaming_options.name: Over IM Rod
reaming_options.description: Standard technique using an intramedullary reamer to set position

reaming_options.name: Guided Reamer
reaming_options.description: Uses a 10mm fixed diameter guide to position the cone independently of the IM canal; allows biasing (M/L/A/P) to cover asymmetric defects or correct alignment without being married to femoral bow

placement_depth_rules.tibia: Flush with proximal tibial cut (or countersunk)
placement_depth_rules.femur: Place 22mm proximal to distal femoral cut to ensure clearance for femoral box and stem adapter

techniques.name: Box-Last Workflow (Dr. Wellman)
steps: Trial stem and rotation without PS box cut first
Once joint line/rotation are set, ream for the box through the trial
This helps ensure the box sits on fresh bone

techniques.name: Countersinking between sizes
techniques.principle: If between sizes, ream for a smaller cone and countersink it rather than over-reaming for a larger size

limitations_and_contraindications: Not a rotating hinge system; indicated up to PS-Max/Constrained level only
Not indicated for massive global ligamentous instability or severe recurvatum requiring a hinge
Requires adequate host bone contact; massive defects may require alternative solutions (e.g., DFR territory); stacked cones have been used off-label

supporting_points: 12° and 18° tapers preserve anterior femoral cortex versus fixed 24° taper designs that can blow out anterior cortex in smaller femurs
1 tray for cones; 3-tray full revision system reduces OR time, sterilization cost, and clutter
Estimated savings up to $1,350 per case due to reduced sterilization burden; supports ASC efficiency
TJO internal data: 44% femoral cone usage vs market average ~11% (AJRR), suggesting competitors avoid femoral cones due to fit challenges
Avoids modular junction (Ti sleeve + CoCr implant) corrosion/metallosis risk associated with sleeves; registry trends show sleeve usage decreasing

pain_points: Fixed 24° taper cones often too wide for femurs; can blow out anterior cortex
tjo_solution: 12° & 18° taper options improve femoral fit and preserve cortex
Solid porous cone structure eliminates modular corrosion risk

pain_points: Historically difficult femoral fit; bulky instrumentation

do_not_claim.do_not_say: The system includes a hinge implant / rotating hinge
do_not_claim.instead_say: System supports ~95% of revisions up to PS-Max/Constrained; not indicated when a hinge is required

do_not_claim.do_not_say: You can rotate the cone in any direction
do_not_claim.instead_say: Cone orientation must follow clearance rules: tibia M/L; femur A/P (90° rotation from tibia)

do_not_claim.do_not_say: Reaming depth is the same for femur and tibia
do_not_claim.instead_say: Femur placement is 22mm proximal to distal femoral cut; tibia is flush (or countersunk)

assessment_schema_suggestions.intent: Optional rubric fields you can use in Replit/OpenAI scoring (edit as desired).

rubric_dimensions.label: Core message accuracy
rubric_dimensions.description: Did the rep correctly explain what Universal Cones are and the top 2–3 differentiators?

rubric_dimensions.label: Clinical & surgical workflow accuracy
rubric_dimensions.description: Did the rep correctly describe indications, ream-only workflow, guided reamer, and depth/orientation rules?

rubric_dimensions.label: Data & proof points
rubric_dimensions.description: Did the rep use key proof points (tray count, $ savings, femoral utilization) without overstating?

rubric_dimensions.label: Competitive positioning
rubric_dimensions.description: Did the rep contrast TJO vs competitors accurately and fairly?

rubric_dimensions.label: Do-not-claim compliance
rubric_dimensions.description: Did the rep avoid prohibited claims (hinge, arbitrary rotation, identical depth)?
